now let us proactively discuss how we're going to handle that situation

i personally i'm very much a big picture type of person i can

huge also by assessing team dynamics it also helps to
overcome one of the greatest barriers to great performance feedback and that is
the fundamental attribution error now the fundamental attribution error is
really just a fancy way of saying that too often times we judge other people
by their behaviors while we judge ourselves by our actions or by our intentions
so we judge other people by their behaviors while we judge ourselves by our intentions i'll give you an example see we see this
quite often in our everyday lives i see this whenever we're driving down the road
see if i'm driving down the road and somebody cuts me off then obviously they're a horrible driver
they're completely inconsiderate we need to take their license away i don't know what they're thinking being on the road
but if i accidentally cut somebody off i didn't
intend to cut them off i i didn't see that the lane was ending so quickly i didn't
expect that i had to uh change lanes so quickly i didn't see the person there and i look at my intentions
we see this within our teams as well and even though we've created an

so we must communicate our expectations uncommuted expectations are doomed to be unmet expectations

and so i encourage you to ask the question if you are have a team member with

said malicious and so i asked the man i said what is your

was to be persuasive and see from here we actually identified
a knowledge gap between intended behavior and perceived behavior

purpose of our feedback is to encourage desired behavior it's to encourage

encouraging desired behavior i encourage you to get specific to get
strategic i recall as a football coach or as a soccer coach sometimes at the end

the players oftentimes left feeling good but not knowing what behavior

encouraging and so i encourage you to get specific to truly
get strategic identify specifically what behavior
you are wanting repeated and what behavior you are encouraging within your team whenever you are giving
that feedback the second purpose of feedback is to
correct undesired behavior
in the same regard uh whenever i was a football coach i had a team member that loved
to come into the halftime come into the locker room at halftime whenever we were losing and
he knew with absolute confidence what we needed to do
to win the game he would come in and he would say guys we just need to play better

yes we did need to play better but we need to ask a series of what's and whys

leads me to the third purpose of feedback and that is to coach or to
build upon existing behavior
